Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding Laser-Assisted Surface Cooling Enhancement (LASCE)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1403508/1402587
Aguilar/Trujillo

This grant provides funding for studying and developing a non-intrusive method to enhance local heat transfer between a target surface and a cooling fluid. The approach takes advantage of thermocavitation bubbles, which are formed when continuous wave (CW) laser light is properly focused within highly-absorbing liquid thin films. These bubbles form and collapse within microseconds, vigorously agitating the liquid and enhancing heat transfer. This phenomenon is called Laser-Assisted Surface Cooling Enhancement (LASCE). The PI's preliminary estimates show that heat transfer enhancement is as great as that of phase change (evaporation/boiling), which is the current upper limit to liquid-based cooling systems. LASCE may also match or exceed the performance obtained using micro-modified structures, but without implementing any type of surface modification. Also, CW lasers are often less complex lasing media, cheaper and simpler than pulse lasers, and can control the frequency of bubble formation simply by modulating their output power. The potential impact of this project, therefore, is in novel ways of controlling surface heat. This has implications for systems ranging from laser surgery to combustion engine devices.

This study encompasses collaborative experimental and computational research between University of California-Riverside and University of Wisconsin-Madison aimed at studying and quantifying the: 1) balance between the heat input to induce thermal cavitation and the cooling produced by enhanced convection; 2) sensitivity of the resulting fluid flow to the operating parameters of the laser and; 3) physics of interaction between multiple cavitation events and its effect on enhanced convective cooling. Based on highly accurate numerical simulations and detailed measurement techniques, a thorough examination of the physics underpinning the most desirable heat transfer conditions will be sought, which is essential in optimizing the operation of LASCE. This will be followed by an equally important objective, which aims to explore LACSE's suitability for applications where surface modification is impossible, such as skin (scalp) cooling during laser therapy across a novel transparent cranial implant ("Window to the Brain") developed at UCR. The success of this project will open the door to many transformative applications of optical thermocavitation aimed at low-temperature combustion strategies for mitigating the levels of NOx and particulate matter emissions to improve engine efficiency as well as transdermal drug delivery for diverse biomedical applications.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cavitation bubbles, previously notorious for forming in fast fluid flows and damaging equipment have gained new interest by researchers in the recent years. The cavitation phenomenon’s rapid mechanical agitation and emission of strong pressure waves has allowed researchers to use them for favorable applications such as microfluidic mixing, cell transfection and micro pumping among others. While there are various methods of inducing cavitation bubbles, bubbles induced via a focused laser (optical cavitation) allow for the accurate and precise control of the bubble location, size and other conditions.  However, for many of these emerging applications, further advancement is limited by the unavoidable heating that comes with irradiating focused light into the medium at play. Only a scarce amount of experimental research has been conducted on the microscale thermal effect of optical cavitation.

 

In this project, we experimentally explored the thermal dynamics that occur during cavitation events. Our forefront motivation for this investigation has been the potential of utilizing laser cavitation for what seems like a paradoxical application: enhanced localized surface cooling. Non-traditional cooling mechanisms are now required to meet the demand of emerging fields such as for short-pulse laser applications and supercomputers. Our research team at the University of California Riverside explored the use of cavitation bubbles as heat transfer enhancers of a target without requiring surface modification or addition of fabricated mechanical components.

 

Our team adopted a temperature measurement technique which has very high resolution (both in space and time) to non-intrusively measure the dynamics surrounding optical cavitation. In doing so, we observed in detail the thermal evolution of thermocavitation bubbles, something not previously studied experimentally. The general project findings indicate that thermocavitation is a superheated process, surpassing the boiling point of the medium. Initially, a boundary layer forms during the duration of the heating time (~100 ms) leading up to cavitation. The growth and collapse of the bubble removes heat up to 50% by acoustic energy, with larger bubbles removing larger percentages. However, the nature of generating thermocavitation quickly introduces the formation of a new boundary layer which builds up before a subsequent bubble is formed. For that reason, it was concluded that low-power thermocavitation is not a sustainable method of enhancing surface cooling. Bubbles generated by pulsed lasers as opposed to continuous wave lasers are preferred for their localized and short-lasting thermal gradients. Experiments with pulsed cavitation are still underway. Parallel studies were carried to gain insight into the dominant physical mechanics governing thermocavitation. The first study involved characterization of optical, fluid (absorption), thermal and pressure influence on single bubble dynamics. The second study was on surface tension and plasmonic resonance effect on bubble dynamics.

 

During this project, 8 graduate and undergraduate students had the opportunity to conduct experiments and present findings to various technical and non-technical audiences. All the undergraduates involved in the project were recruited from UC Riverside’s Mentoring Summer Research Internship Program (MSRIP) which is a program designed to increase the participation in STEM by underrepresented minorities. Further, our team and collaborative partners developed a Binational USA-Mexico Symposium of Laser-Induced Cavitation and its applications. This project as a whole, has helped expand the current knowledge of cavitation and how we can use the phenomenon’s full potential in various fields.


Last Modified: 08/06/2018
Modified by: Guillermo Aguilar
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Cavitation bubbles, previously notorious for forming in fast fluid flows and damaging equipment have gained new interest by researchers in the recent years. The cavitation phenomenon?s rapid mechanical agitation and emission of strong pressure waves has allowed researchers to use them for favorable applications such as microfluidic mixing, cell transfection and micro pumping among others. While there are various methods of inducing cavitation bubbles, bubbles induced via a focused laser (optical cavitation) allow for the accurate and precise control of the bubble location, size and other conditions. However, for many of these emerging applications, further advancement is limited by the unavoidable heating that comes with irradiating focused light into the medium at play. Only a scarce amount of experimental research has been conducted on the microscale thermal effect of optical cavitation. In this project, we experimentally explored the thermal dynamics that occur during cavitation events. Our forefront motivation for this investigation has been the potential of utilizing laser cavitation for what seems like a paradoxical application: enhanced localized surface cooling. Non-traditional cooling mechanisms are now required to meet the demand of emerging fields such as for short-pulse laser applications and supercomputers. Our research team at the University of California Riverside explored the use of cavitation bubbles as heat transfer enhancers of a target without requiring surface modification or addition of fabricated mechanical components. Our team adopted a temperature measurement technique which has very high resolution (both in space and time) to non-intrusively measure the dynamics surrounding optical cavitation. During this project, 8 graduate and undergraduate students had the opportunity to conduct experiments and present findings to various technical and non-technical audiences. Further, our team and collaborative partners developed a Binational USA-Mexico Symposium of Laser-Induced Cavitation and its applications. This project as a whole, has helped expand the current knowledge of cavitation and how we can use the phenomenon?s full potential in various fields.
